subsubsection.title: Graph log functions
subsubsection.p: One way to graph a log function is to first make a table of values for its inverse function, the exponential function with the same base, then interchange the variables.

subsubsection.title: Use function notation
subsubsection.p: A log function is the inverse of the exponential function with the same base, and vice versa.

li.p: But ~3^{a+b}~ is not equivalent to ~3^a+3^b;~ in fact ~3^{a+b} =3^a \cdot 3^b.
So for this function, f(a+b) \not= f(a)+f(b).
But ~\log_3 {(a+b)}~ is not equivalent to ~\log_3 {(a)} +\log_3 {9};~ in fact ~\log_3 {(ab)} = \log_3 {(a)} +\log_3 {(b)}.
So for this function, f(a+b) \not= f(a)+f(b).

subsubsection.title: Use the properties of logarithms
subsubsection.p: The three properties of logarithms are helpful in making computations involving logs.
